title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States. Automotive sales historically accounted for a significant portion of retail spending, providing income for millions of Americans. Sales peaked in June 2006 at 17,500,000 units and dropped to 14,200,000 units in May 2008, still above the 13,000,000 unit threshold for a robust industry. In 2008, the automotive industry's annual sales revenue was substantial, with new vehicle dealers contributing significantly to the national economy. The average sales revenue for around 20,000 new automobile dealers in the US was $28.8 million, totaling $576 billion for all new-vehicle dealerships, representing 14.6% of total retail sales. Additionally, 1,057,500 individuals were employed in new-vehicle dealerships in the US in 2008. In 2008, 1,057,500 employees in new-vehicle dealerships in the United States earned an average of $48,963 per year, generating over $52 billion in national payroll. A financially sound dealer network is crucial for the success of automobile manufacturers, benefiting the national economy. The reduction in the cost of capital needed to finance new vehicle purchases will benefit the new-vehicle dealer industry, automotive manufacturing industry, and national economy. Nonmortgage interest payments, like automobile loan debt, were deductible for Federal income tax until 1986. The deduction for interest on indebtedness incurred to acquire a passenger car or light truck was eliminated in 1986. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subparagraph (G) regarding qualified vehicle interest for the acquisition of a qualified vehicle. The average national unemployment rate must be at least 7 percent for the preceding calendar quarter. Additionally, the definition of qualified vehicle interest is revised for this purpose. The term "qualified vehicle interest" refers to interest properly chargeable on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, limited to $5,000 over a 36-month period. The term "qualified vehicle interest" refers to interest properly chargeable on debt incurred to acquire a qualified vehicle, limited to $5,000 over a 36-month period. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle acquired for personal use by the taxpayer, with no payment made under section 1302. The term "qualified vehicle interest" refers to interest on debt for acquiring a qualified vehicle, limited to $5,000 over 36 months. A qualified vehicle is a motor vehicle for personal use, made by a manufacturer, treated as a motor vehicle under the Clean Air Act, with a weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, and is a passenger automobile or light truck. The term "motor vehicle" refers to any vehicle manufactured primarily for public road use with at least 4 wheels, as defined by the Environmental Protection Agency regulations for the Clean Air Act. The text chunk discusses amendments related to the national unemployment rate and deductions allowed in computing adjusted gross income under the Clean Air Act. The amendments made by this section shall be effective as specified. The deduction for qualified vehicle interest under section 163(h)(5) applies to vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
